close_symbols: struct MHD_BasicAuthInfo (definition: username, username_len, password, password_len)
strcmp, strlen, memcmp (standard C library functions)
explanation:
Explain why each symbol is required to check the MISRA rule that a function parameter shall not be modified:

- req_cls (parameter: void **)
  - Central to the rule check: the function assigns to *req_cls (writes the object pointed to) but never assigns to req_cls itself. Knowing the exact type (void **) is required to decide whether the code modifies the pointer parameter variable or the object it points to.

- aptr (static int local)
  - The code stores &aptr into *req_cls. Knowing aptr is a local static lets you determine that the stored value is an address of a local object (and that the function is not assigning to the req_cls parameter itself). Also needed to reason about whether taking its address has any effect on the parameter variable.

- struct MHD_BasicAuthInfo (definition: username, username_len, password, password_len)
  - The function reads fields from auth_info returned by MHD_basic_auth_get_username_password3. Knowing the structure layout confirms these accesses are to the object returned and not aliases of any function parameter; it’s needed to be sure no parameter is being reassigned via these fields.

- MHD_basic_auth_get_username_password3 (prototype)
  - This callee is called with connection. To be safe under the MISRA rule you must confirm that this function does not take the address of any of ahc_echo’s parameters (i.e. &connection, &req_cls, etc.) or otherwise have side effects that reassign ahc_echo’s parameter variables. Its prototype/signature (and whether it takes pointer-to-pointer arguments) is required to rule that out.

- MHD_free (prototype)
  - Frees auth_info. Knowing its prototype shows it cannot reassign any of ahc_echo’s parameters (it only takes a pointer to memory to free), so it does not violate the rule by modifying parameters.

- MHD_create_response_from_buffer_static (prototype)
  - Used to create response objects. Include prototype to confirm it does not accept addresses of ahc_echo parameters (no way to reassign those parameters) and thus cannot modify the parameter variables.

- MHD_queue_basic_auth_required_response3 (prototype)
  - Called with connection and response; confirm it does not accept addresses of ahc_echo parameters or otherwise reassign them.

- MHD_queue_response (prototype)
  - Called with connection and response; include prototype to confirm it cannot modify ahc_echo’s parameter variables (only operates on the objects pointed to).

- MHD_destroy_response (prototype)
  - Destroys response object. Prototype confirms it does not take addresses of ahc_echo’s parameters and thus cannot reassign them.

- strcmp, strlen, memcmp (standard C library functions)
  - These functions are used against method, username, password, upload_data_size etc. Knowing their signatures (they accept pointers by value) confirms they cannot reassign ahc_echo parameter variables.

Together these symbols let the next analyst determine (1) which assignments in ahc_echo target the parameter variable itself versus the object pointed to, and (2) whether any called functions could legitimately reassign ahc_echo’s parameter variables via being passed their addresses or via other side effects. With these symbols one can conclude whether ahc_echo assigns to any parameter variable (a MISRA violation) or only to objects referenced by pointer parameters (permitted).
